Title: Best movies by Yasujirō Ozu
Description: My most favourite movies of master Ozu! One of the great Japanese masters of cinema, Ozu was known for his famed tatami shot and themes involving family and interpersonal relationships. His most highly acclaimed film is Tokyo Story but is just the beginning.

Title: They aren't films; they're experiences
Description: Recently, I've become aware that certain films are able to transcend the medium by being completely self-assured in their atmospheres and worlds that they build. Often, these worlds are able to get under the viewer's skin and stay with them for quite some time, for better or worse.

Title: Best movies by Abbas Kiarostami
Description: Godard once said: "Film begins with DW Griffith and ends with Abbas Kiarostami." Scorsese followed: "Kiarostami represents the highest level of artistry in the cinema." I've come to admire the truth in both expressions.

Title: “old films” for people who want to watch more “old films” but don’t know where to start
Description: A year ago I would constantly tell myself I wanted to get into classic films more, but all my attempts led me to boredom. Thankfully, I got myself out of that mindset, and now the world of cinema is expansive and my options are never limited.

Title: Best of Andrei Tarkovsky
Description: Andrei Tarkovsky was a Soviet filmmaker, writer, film editor, film theorist and opera director, widely regarded as one of the finest filmmakers of the 20th century. Tarkovsky's films include Andrei Rublev, Solaris, Mirror and Stalker. They are characterized by spirituality and metaphysical themes, long takes, lack of conventional dramatic structure and plot, and distinctively authored use of cinematography.

Title: Best of Japanese classic movies
Description: Russia’s most cryptically poetic, exhaustive, metaphysical, Malick-esque filmmaker. Yes, I am a glutton for punishment. Few directors are more fascinating, frustrating, and fulfilling—all at the same time. He’s the anti-Eisenstein of Russia. Slow, but with purpose. A master of mood, space, and time. Lets you breathe, think, and reassess. Challenging, but never forgettable.

Title: Japanese Films That Will Blow Your Mind And Make You Reevaluate The Possibilities Of The Cinematic Artform

Title: Best of Masaki Kobayashi

Title: old hollywood for beginners
Description: there was a time when i really didn't like (or thought i didn't like) old films. i found them dull, boring and i just couldn't concentrate on them. then i saw 12 angry men and LOVED it, which really surprised me, so i watched a few more (sunset boulevard, vertigo) and realised i just hadn't found any old films that i'd really loved, and now i ADORE old hollywood. so i thought i'd make this list for people who think they don't like old films and now i'm rambling so i'll stop.
